Text: The Sun accounts for more than 99% of the mass of the entire solar system.
A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
Saturn's rings are mostly made of ice and rock particles.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all Earth's beaches.
Light from the Sun takes about 8 minutes and 20 seconds to reach Earth.
Jupiter has the strongest magnetic field of all planets in the solar system.
A black hole's gravity is so strong that not even light can escape.
Neutron stars can spin hundreds of times per second.
The universe is about 13.8 billion years old.
The coldest known place in the universe is the Boomerang Nebula, at -272°C.
Mars has the tallest mountain in the solar system, Olympus Mons, almost three times taller than Mount Everest.
The International Space Station (ISS) travels at about 28,000 km/h.
The Milky Way is about 100,000 light-years in diameter.
A light-year is the distance light travels in one year – about 9.46 trillion km.
It can rain diamonds on Saturn.
Space is completely silent because sound cannot travel through a vacuum.
Stars are born in giant clouds of gas and dust called nebulae.
The Moon moves about 3.8 cm away from Earth every year.
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.
The hottest planet in the solar system is Venus, even though Mercury is closer to the Sun.
There are more than 200 billion stars in the Milky Way.
An asteroid killed the dinosaurs about 66 million years ago.
Sunspots are cooler areas on the Sun's surface.
The first human in space was Yuri Gagarin in 1961.
The Hubble Space Telescope has been in operation since 1990.
Saturn's moon Titan has lakes and rivers of liquid methane and ethane.
Space tourism is becoming commercially possible.
Most stars in the Milky Way are red dwarfs.
The universe is expanding faster and faster.
The largest known star is UY Scuti, about 1,700 times the Sun's diameter.
On Mars, the sky is pink during the day and blue at sunset.
A supernova can shine brighter than its entire galaxy.
Black holes can collide and create gravitational waves.
It takes 225 million years for the Sun to orbit once around the Milky Way.
Mercury has almost no atmosphere.
The ISS has been visited by astronauts from over 15 countries.
A day on Jupiter lasts only 10 hours.
The longest spacewalk lasted 8 hours and 56 minutes.
On the Moon, footprints can remain for millions of years.
Mars has two moons – Phobos and Deimos.
The universe may contain over two trillion galaxies.
Earth is the only known planet with liquid water on its surface.
A black hole can distort time around it.
Saturn's moon Enceladus sprays water vapor into space.
The closest star after the Sun is Proxima Centauri.
Light from the Andromeda Galaxy takes about 2.5 million years to reach us.
Jupiter has more than 90 known moons.
A comet is made of ice, rock, and dust.
The solar wind is a stream of charged particles from the Sun.
Astronauts float in space not because there is no gravity, but because they are in free fall.
The first animals in orbit were fruit flies in 1947.
Mars may have had oceans billions of years ago.
The universe became transparent to light about 380,000 years after the Big Bang.
The Moon has no atmosphere, so the sky is always black.
Shooting stars are actually meteors burning up in the atmosphere.
There is a galaxy that smells like rum and tastes like raspberries (Sagittarius B2).
There are more molecules in a cup of water than there are stars in the universe.
The Sun does not burn; it undergoes nuclear fusion.
Mars has seasons just like Earth.
There are planets that float freely in space without a star.
The largest known galaxy is IC 1101, over 6 million light-years in diameter.
If you fell into a black hole, time would slow down for you relative to the outside world.
Venus rotates backwards compared to most planets.
The universe has no center.
Astronauts grow taller in space because their spines stretch out.
Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a storm that has lasted at least 350 years.
Saturn could float in water if there were a large enough ocean.
A day on the Moon is about 29 Earth days long.
Neptune has the fastest winds in the solar system – up to 2,100 km/h.
The Milky Way and Andromeda will collide in about 4 billion years.
There are planets where it rains glass sideways.
The average temperature of the universe is -270°C.
Most meteors burn up before reaching Earth's surface.
The first satellite in space was Sputnik 1 in 1957.
Stars can live for billions of years.
There are dwarf galaxies orbiting the Milky Way.
Astronauts can see 16 sunrises and sunsets each day on the ISS.
A white dwarf is the final stage of many stars' lives.
The largest moon in the solar system is Ganymede.
Some galaxies are moving away from us faster than light due to the expansion of the universe.
A day on Neptune is about 16 hours long.
Space smells, according to astronauts, like welding fumes and grilled meat.
Meteorite impacts occur on Earth every day, but most are small.
A pulsar is a type of rotating neutron star that emits radio waves.
Saturn's rings are only a few hundred meters thick.
The first woman in space was Valentina Tereshkova in 1963.
The Sun will eventually become a red giant and swallow the inner planets.
A galaxy can contain hundreds of billions of planets.
Jupiter acts as a 'shield' and catches many comets.
Some stars explode and leave behind black holes.
The Moon has volcanic mountains, but they are inactive.
There are planets with multiple sunrises each day.
The Sun's surface is about 5,500°C.
The universe might be infinite.
Astronauts train underwater to prepare for weightlessness.
It can rain sulfuric acid on Venus.
Spacecraft can use gravity assists to travel faster.
Most comets come from the Oort Cloud.
There may be more planets in the universe than stars.
The cosmic microwave background is an echo of the Big Bang.
